channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: NPR CEO Katherine Maher discusses the future of public radio
item.description: NPR CEO Katherine Maher answers questions on the future of public radio as Congress strips over $1 billion from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Congress rolls back $9 billion in public media funding and foreign aid, Trump threatens to sue Wall Street Journal over article about Epstein ties, Trump diagnosed with common circulatory condition.

item.title: HBO's 'Billy Joel: And So It Goes' chronicles the life of the iconic musician
item.description: A new HBO two-part documentary chronicles the life and work of one of America's most successful singer/songwriters, Billy Joel.

item.title: Despite rising inflation and tariff threats, Americans have kept up their spending
item.description: Despite inflation and tariff worries, retail spending data from June shows Americans still shopping with gusto. Economists cite low unemployment, bargain hunting and tariff fatigue.

item.title: Chicago Fed's Austan Goolsbee discusses the health of the U.S. economy
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Austan Goolsbee, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, about the health of the U.S. economy.

item.title: U.S. politicians want to reshore manufacturing. But what makes it so special?
item.description: One hope for reshoring manufacturing is it could help revitalize the heartland. NPR's Planet Money team dives deep into the economic theory and evidence behind this idea.

item.title: Congress sends bill cutting public media and foreign aid funding to Trump
item.description: House Republicans delivered a major victory to President Trump early Friday, passing Trump's rescissions bill that claws back $9 billion in funds already approved for public media and foreign aid.

item.title: Filmmaker Ken Burns on how cuts to funding for public media could affect Americans
item.description: Filmmaker Ken Burns tells NPR's Michel Martin about the role that federal funding has played in his documentary work and the potential impact of the loss of that funding on children's programming.

item.title: Two park rangers recall being the first to clean Mt. Rushmore
item.description: In this StoryCorps, two park rangers recall being part of a team specially trained to brave the heights and wash the four faces of the presidents on Mt. Rushmore — something no one had ever attempted.

item.title: White House says President Trump has a common circulatory condition
item.description: President Trump has been diagnosed with a relatively common medical condition called chronic venous insufficiency that is affecting the veins in his legs, according to the White House.
